sect2.title: Contents
sect2.para: All packages which have been, at some moment, aprt of &d-i; translation levels, are no more used directly during the install process, but are considered important enough for being translated are part of level 5 of &d-i; localization.

This includes the following Debian packages:
debconf (debconf)
debconf (program)
shadow (program)
newt
aptitude
console-common
dictionaries-common
dpkg
apt
dpkg and apt are very often used during the whole life of a Debian system, so having them translated, though very tedious, is a must-have for a good localized system.

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: The debconf Debian package is the program which handles all configuration steps of other packages when these packages need some user interaction while they are configured.

This package is installed on all Debian systems. Its installation process usually inputs the user about the default priority of questions. However, when installed in a normal &d-i; installation process, these answers are pre-filled with the priority settings of the installation process. As a consequence, the questions are usually hidden from users.
However, as the package is a key Debian package, its translation is important for a properly localized system.

sect3.title: Files location and access methods
sect3.para: The package uses a SVN repository. Commit access may be requested to the &i18n-coords;. However, as the translatable parts do not change very often, getting commit access is not highly useful.

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: Translations should be reported as bugs against the debconf package.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: The translations are very similar to the questions asked by the cdebconf package, which is part of the level1 of &d-i; translations.

Translators should then be careful about using the same terminology in both packages, especially for questions priorities. This can be done by merging the translations from &d-i; level1 into debconf translations.

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: The debconf program is the software which is used for user interaction during Debian packages configuration step. All Debian packages should use debconf when they need user input for installation-time configuration.
debconf may output information to the screen: this is why the program translation is included in &d-i; fourth level of translation.

Debconf also prompts users with questions when installed. However, during a complete &d-i; run, these questions are pre-answered with the similar questions from the cdebconf package (which is part of level 1). As a consequence, the translation of these questions is only part of level 5.

sect3.title: Files location and access methods
sect3.para: The package uses a SVN repository. Commit access may be requested to the &i18n-coords;. However, as the translatable parts do not change very often, getting commit access is not highly useful.

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: Translations should be reported as bugs against the debconf package or committed directly to the SVN repository.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: N/A

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: The utilities installed by this package have been internationalized and, as they are core utilities for a Debian system, translating them is important to achieve a good localization of the installed system.

This translation is, like apt and dpkg translations, a program translation: programs (like passwd, chpw, chsh, etc.) output, error and help messages. Such translation is quite tedious and long term work and need some carefulness (respect line breaks, variable substitutions...).

sect3.title: Files location and access methods
sect3.para: This package is a regular Debian package. Programs translations are maintained by the upstream maintainer who uses a CVS repository.

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: Translations should be reported as bugs against the shadow package. The upstream maintainer will pick them from there.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: Upstream has a monthly release schedule with usually one week string freeze before each release. Call for updates will be sent during this string freeze.
Uploads of the Debian package will occur one or two weeks after upstream has released his new version.

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: The newt package is a library (whiptail) which includes widgets used by the most popular interface to the debconf software, the software involved in packages configuration steps. These widgets include the Yes or No widgets used by boolean templates, as well as the OK or Abort buttons text.

sect3.title: Files location and access methods
sect3.para: No public revision control repository is available for this package so access through the translation statistics pages is the only way to get translation material for it:

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: Translations should be reported as bugs against the newt package.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: N/A

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: The aptitude program is an combination of interactive and non-interactive tools for installing Debian packages. For long-time users of Debian, it may be seen as the replacement for both dselect and apt-get.
It is used from base-config when packages are installed. It is also used interactively when the user chooses the option for installing individual packages of his/her choice.
The program uses a text-based menu system when used interactively and includes a lot of output messages when it is run non-interactively.

aptitude's full translation is a huge work because there are hundreds of strings in the POT file. Moreover, this requires some good knowledge of several Debian package managements concepts. It is recommended that this translation is handled by an experienced Debian system administrator.

sect3.title: Files location and access methods
sect3.para: This package is a regular Debian package. The package maintainer uses a darcs repository for the program development (the Debian package is handled in a separate SVN repository).

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: Translations should be reported as bugs against the aptitude package.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: Without any doubt, aptitude's translation is among the most difficult translations involved in &d-i; translation. It has an impact far outside &d-i; because aptitude is likely to be used all along the life of a Debian system.
Several strings in aptitude PO file are menu entries, pseudo dialog boxes text and all such limited size material. The source code is not very widely commented to help out translators.

The ideal way to translate aptitude is by recompiling the software and include the translation to be tested. Compiling aptitude requires usual build tools and software as well as a few dedicated libraries such as apt libraries.

Aptitude also includes a small help file, which may be translated as well. However, this translation does not use GNU gettext, so the translation is quite tricky. See the help* files in aptitude's source tree.
Aptitude's documentation may also be translated. See the doc/ directory in the package's source tree.

Translators should be aware that aptitude is still under heavy development, so upstream strings are very likely to change or be added. Anyway, even a partial translation will help the users of a given language.
The aptitude maintainer has written a special README.i18n file to give more details to translators. The contents of this file follows, as of the day of this documentation was written.
Aptitude uses the standard gettext mechanism for translations. However, there are a few twists that you should be aware of.

sect4.title: External data files
sect4.para: There are several external data files that you can choose to translate: help.txt (online help), help-mine.txt (online help for Minesweeper), and aptitude.xml (user's manual/online manual). aptitude.xml is a large file, but help.txt and help-mine.txt are quite tractable and it is recommended that you translate them. (especially help.txt)
aptitude applies gettext to the file names before loading them, so to tell it that you've translated (eg) help.txt to help-de.txt, you should add a translation "help.txt" -> "help-de.txt".
In addition, each translated file name has a corresponding described translation (see below) indicating its encoding. You should translate this as necessary if you write an alternate file.

sect4.title: Manpage
sect4.para: aptitude has a manpage, and it can be translated; if you choose to translate it, your translation should be named aptitude.XX.1 (replace XX with the language code)

sect4.title: fragf
sect4.para: aptitude uses an internal function called fragf to format text with display attributes. This function works somewhat like printf, but most escape codes have different meanings. For instance, %B enables the "bold" character attribute, while %b disables it. See src/vscreen/fragment.h for a full description of all escape codes. You can use parameter numbers (eg, %1$F) if your language needs to reorder the arguments.

sect4.title: Key translations
sect4.para: Where it makes sense, aptitude allows the default keybinding assigned to a command to be translated. This is done by creating a dummy translated string ending in "_key"; the first character of the string is the default binding of the key. For instance, the string "yes_key" is used to set the default binding for buttons labelled "Yes". To bind "j" to this command, you could translate "yes_key" to "ja_key", "ja", or even just "j".

sect4.title: Described translations
sect4.para:
Some translations have descriptions or disambiguating text to the left of the input and output string. In these cases, everything up to and including the first pipe character will be removed before the string is used. If no pipe character is present in the string, the string will be used without modifications.
For instance, the string "help.txt encoding|UTF-8" can be translated to either "help.txt encoding|ISO-8859-1", "|ISO-8859-1", or "ISO-8859-1", and will have the same effect in each case.

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: The console-common package includes all tools for handling the console (input and output).

It is installed and configured as part of the Debian base system. Its configuration process involves some user input and may be shown to users during a base system install, in some occasions (but not always).

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: Translations should be reported as bugs against the console-common package.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: N/A

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: The dictionaries-common package includes all common tools for using word dictionaries in Debian.

It is installed and configured as part of the Debian base system. Its configuration process inputs the user for choosing a word dictionary when the installation is run at medium priority (using the expert mode of install...or when some problem occurred earlier in the installation process).

sect3.title: Files location and access methods
sect3.para: This package is a regular Debian package. The package maintainer currently does no use any CVS or SVN repository.

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: Translations should be reported as bugs against the dictionaries-common package.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: N/A

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: The dpkg program is a low level program which installs and removes Debian packages.

Including it in &d-i; level 4 of translation is an extension of the scope of &d-i; localization process. dpkg does not output very often during a base system install, but is very likely to be used further, either directly invoked by the system administrator or from another program such as aptitude, apt, or dselect (dselect translations are part of dpkg translations).

dpkg full translation is a huge work because there are hundreds of strings in the POT file. Most of these strings are very short strings and most of them are hard-formatted because they are used from a command-line program.

sect3.title: Files location and access methods
sect3.para: This package is a regular Debian package. The package maintenance team uses a SVN repository to maintain it.

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: Translations should be reported as bugs against the dpkg package or commited directly to the SVN repository. Don't forget updating the po/Changelog and debian/changelog files if you update the translations yourself by getting SVN commit access.
If reported as a bug, the translation will be committed quickly by the dpkg localization maintainer.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: Undoubtfully, dpkg translation requires a good knowledge of the Debian package management system as well as some good experience of command-line programs translation.
The developers have put comments targeted at translators for some strings. Translators should read and follow them carefully.
The po/ directory contains a file named Changelog. Translators must update this file when updating translations, as well as the debian/changelog file.
Adding a new language also requires translators to add it to the po/LINGUAS file. Otherwise, the new translation will not be used.
dpkg man pages can also be translated, using gettext files. Please look into the man/ directory in SVN for examples.

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: The apt program handles installation and removal of Debian packages from packages sources such as Debian HTTP/FTP mirrors, Debian CD's, third party CD's or repositories, or local files.

Including it in &d-i; level 4 of translation is an extension of the scope of &d-i; localization process. apt does not output very often during a base system install, but is very likely to be used further.

sect3.title: Files location and access methods
sect3.para: This package is a regular Debian package. The package maintenance team uses arch repositories to maintain it.
As arch-style repositories are somewhat complicated to setup, all localization of apt is handled by one of the &i18n-coords;.

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: Translations should be reported as bugs against the apt package.

The translation will be committed quickly by the dpkg localization maintainer. This will not appear immediately on status pages because apt development is handled in arch repositories which are not easily handled by the scripts which generate the status pages.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: apt full translation is a huge work because there are hundreds of strings in the POT file. Most of these strings are short strings and most of them are hard-formatted because they are outputted during the use of a command-line program.
Similarly to dpkg, apt translation requires a good knowledge of the Debian package management system as well as some good experience of command-line programs translation.
The developers have put comments targeted at translators for some strings. Translators should read them carefully. Some of them are very important.
